title: Accessibility-Aware Computer-Use Agents
subtitle: LSTM-based POMDP Policies for Inclusive AI
agency: University of Michigan Human-AI Lab (Prof. Anhong Guo)
description: Systematically investigating SOTA computer-use agents under preregistered accessibility constraints with rigorous benchmarking and LSTM-based POMDP decision policies.

body.title: Research Problem
paragraphs: State-of-the-art computer-use agents (CUAs) operate under assumptions of full visual and mouse access, failing catastrophically when users require accessibility modes like Keyboard-Only, Screen-Reader, or High-Zoom navigation.

No existing benchmarks rigorously quantify the modality gap between standard and accessibility-constrained interactions, nor do current agents adapt their decision-making to capability-aware observations.

body.title: Technical Approach
paragraphs: Built a capability-aware benchmark with preregistered accessibility constraints (Keyboard-Only, Screen-Reader, High-Zoom) and rigorously defined metrics including success rate, latency, action/error counts, and F1–F8 failure taxonomy with Wilson confidence intervals and Cliff's δ effect sizes.

Prototyped an LSTM-based Partially Observable Markov Decision Process (POMDP) decision policy that maps capability-aware observations to reliable keyboard/screen-reader actions, trained via Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) followed by Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) with action masking and compatibility regularization.
Conducted controlled interventions to quantify failure modes and systematically map the modality gap in a fully reproducible evaluation suite.

body.title: Impact & Outcomes
paragraphs: Established the first rigorous benchmark for evaluating computer-use agents under accessibility constraints, enabling systematic measurement of the modality gap.
Developed decision policies that can potentially close the performance gap between standard and accessibility-constrained modes, making AI agents usable for millions of users with disabilities.
Research contributes to human-centered AI by ensuring autonomous agents work equitably across diverse user capabilities and interaction modalities.
